Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Citizenship, Property, and Law in the Reintegration of Internally Displaced Persons

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Graduate student, Irina Levin, under the supervision Dr. Bruce Grant of New York University, will explore how law shapes the return process for deported minority populations. Focusing on a group of Meskhetian Turks in Georgia and Azerbaijan as its sample this research uses ethnographic methods including participant-observation, in-depth, semi-structured interviews, and archival and textual analysis to examine how internally displaced persons (IDPs) experience and interpret the process of return. The study's central questions are: (1) how returnees' efforts at reintegration are shaped by their entanglements with local, national, and international legal orders; (2) what their experiences suggest for other displaced and stateless peoples across the world. This research builds on anthropological and interdisciplinary research on law, the nature of citizenship, and the transformations of postsocialist property to offer novel anthropological insights to augment our understanding of refugees, repatriation, and reintegration throughout the world.

This research addresses broad intellectual and logistical questions regarding displaced people. According to recent estimates from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, there are 15.4 million refugees and 27.5 million IDPs. As displacement has become an increasingly prevalent social, political, and logistical problem, it has also become an area of theoretical concern for anthropology and other social science disciplines. In terms both abstract and acutely practical, we are pressed to ask: Where do such persons belong? How can they and the countries they come to inhabit be made more secure? Through long-term ethnographic fieldwork this study sheds light on three domains that play a crucial role in the return process -- law, citizenship, and property. This study provides a timely examination of the issues that today's refugees and IDPs will encounter in the years to come.

By focusing on the struggles of former deportees as they attempt to become citizens, property owners, and active participants in the legal and democratic processes in post-Soviet Georgia, this research will reveal the practical, political, and social challenges faced by IDPs and international organizations. As such, this research has the potential to inform our understanding in areas including democratization, anti-corruption, and the rule of law. Further, the study's location in two South Caucasus nations will augment our knowledge of this important but poorly-understood region. By focusing on legislation and its impact on a vulnerable population, this research seeks to highlight areas of concern for US and international governmental and non-governmental organizations engaged with work on all aspects of displacement and its long-term aftermaths, including return movements, repatriation legislation, and reintegration programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My ethnographic research examines the long-term consequences of forced migration. Meskhetian Turks, a community displaced from Georgia in 1944, are Turkish-speaking Muslims. Their deportation from the Soviet-Turkish border region is often explained in terms of suspected disloyalty and this issue continues to complicate their efforts of integration and return. During the course of a twelve-month fieldwork period, I worked with Meskhetian Turks in three settings: In Azerbaijan, I worked with possible future returnees, some of whom were engaged in the legal process of repatriation. In Georgia, I worked with returnees in the midst of reintegration into Georgian society, a process sometimes complicated by a lack of Georgian citizenship. Finally, in Turkey I worked with those who have staked their claim to an alternative homeland. My other interlocutors have been social scientists, NGO workers, human rights activists, and government officials in all three countries who have worked on the legal and practical aspects of the repatriation, reintegration, and migration processes.

Having completed my fieldwork, I argue that 1) Law, and specifically legal frameworks that are based on humanitarian ideals, can and sometimes does serve to magnify uncertainty in the lives of displaced people. That is, I have found that such laws are useful tools for states interested in controlling and discouraging certain forms of mobility. In Georgia, researchers have previously discussed how international humanitarian funds aimed at assisting Internally Displaced Persons have been redirected into funding state security structures that, through the threat of violence, were then used to silence dissent (Dunn and Cowley 2005). Similarly, I argue that the legal framework for the voluntary repatriation of Meskhetian Turks, provided to Georgia by an international human rights community dominated by Western models, has been redirected as a means of controlling and deterring Meskhetian Turks’ in-migration. For the few that do reach Georgia, this framework also provides a pretext for depriving them of a workable means of becoming citizens.

2) My research further suggests that “insecure” states’ conceptions of citizens’ loyalty create particularly unfavorable conditions for victims of forced displacement and their descendants. In Georgia and Azerbaijan, insecurity stems from a variety of factors, including areas of sovereign territory that are outside of state control, antagonistic relationships with neighboring countries, and citizens’ lack of faith in state institutions. These states’ concern with citizens’ loyalty has stigmatized dual citizenship. For people such as Meskhetians, who were deported as Soviet citizens and later became citizens of newly independent countries, this antipathy toward official recognition of dual or multiple citizenships creates problems in regularizing their residency status, attaining employment, accessing basic education and health benefits, and in numerous other arenas of daily life. Conversely, lives spent in multiple countries, and perhaps dual or multiple citizenships, have led to a range of practical benefits and affective connections. Their loyalty is, as these states fear, complicated by life histories of exaggerated mobility. However, it is further complicated, and perhaps even shattered, by these states attempts to ensure security through stringent regulations aimed at guaranteeing citizens’ loyalty.

3) My research also leads me to conclude that Meskhetian Turks today see mobility as a key component of building stable lives. That is, they view the ability to cross international borders in a predictable fashion and safe from any official or unofficial harassment as necessary to ensuring their livelihoods and the future of their community.
